content: About the monthly async newsletter
I'd be interested to take the lead on writing it
It's the 31st, so maybe we should compile a list of noteworthy topics for the january (and december?) post?
cc @nikomatsakis @tmandry
That would be great, thanks! (Unless others have plans, but I don’t know of anything)

On the interoperability side of things, I’ve been iterating on the design of async read and write traits, and how completion based io (iocp, io_uring) will fit into the async traits. Next I plan to look at writing that all up and the async buf read/write traits
@Ibraheem Ahmed that would be great :)
maybe we can write updates during sprint planning meetings?
it probably helps to summarize what happened before we go into retrospective mode
@Ibraheem Ahmed Should I take the call for help out of the blog post then? I'm not sure how much help you want :)
You can take it out, yes.
I should be fine on my own, assuming everyone here pitches in with explanation where needed.
@Ibraheem Ahmed the initiative owners left summaries in the previous sprint section of the sprint doc
:+1:
Are we aiming for end of february?
@Ibraheem Ahmed that does seem reasonable, since we just published the blog post
do you have ideas of where to publish?
it could go on our website, or a dedicated RSS feed, or an email newsletter.. I don't have strong opinions here :)
I guess the main thing is that people should be able to subscribe to the newsletter specifically
without having to e.g. watch for all activity on our repo

tmandry said:

I guess the main thing is that people should be able to subscribe to the newsletter specifically

Yeah.
https://blog.rust-lang.org/async similar to https://blog.rust-lang.org/inside-rust maybe?
And maybe announce that it's starting, on the main blog.
Perhaps post it to Inside Rust directly, and tag it if people want to be able to subset that feed?

A new blog alongside inside-rust seems like it probably merits quite a bit of discussion, I'm not sure it feels appropriate to me (at the very least, we should likely spend more time before spinning that up for just async, and a proliferation of various blogs seems more harmful than helpful given our low volume, IMO).

I'd be happy to review a PR adding the team as a tag to the RSS feeds generated by the Rust scripts in the blog; I don't think we support that today but it seems reasonable to do so.
I think that having the ability to "filter" inside rust by team would be great
it was something we thought about initially
+1 to that
I've started the draft for jan/feb
The sprint doc doesn't have many items that were actually completed :sweat_smile:
Maybe people could write a brief summary of important things that happened/started?
Or links to PRs, blog posts, etc. that could be summarized

Oh yeah, I published this:

  • https://blog.yoshuawuyts.com/futures-concurrency-3

I believe Niko published:

  • https://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps//blog/2022/01/27/panics-vs-cancellation-part-1
  • https://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps//blog/2022/01/07/dyn-async-traits-part-7

Nrc published:

  • https://www.ncameron.org/blog/async-read-and-write-traits/
  • https://www.ncameron.org/blog/async-io-fundamentals/

Not sure if anyone else published things in jan/feb?
Those are the one's I'm aware of, but I've only been following a subset of the intiatives
I also think things like pin! deserve a shoutout
is there a link to the latest on pin! ?
We now have std::pin::pin! on nightly: https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/std/pin/macro.pin.html

@Ibraheem Ahmed did you ever make progress here? I was getting some questions about our status and I realized that pointing folks at this monthly newsletter would fill the gap.

I was thinking, maybe a nice thing to do would be for you to write up some structure but then leave gaps for the various area leads to write notes about their goals? (e.g., @tmandry and I could write about progress with async fn in traits ...)
I am aiming to post the draft this weekend :+1:
Here's the draft: https://hackmd.io/3K0cUmBcQPqlxda-Kcmaug?view
Open to any suggestions regarding structure, etc.
